#5

Coelacanths, and he was wrong in saying that there was only one caught. There are two extant of coelacanths- both have been caught. For more info on lobe-finned fishes, google "sarcopterygian" and "actinista"

#8

In taxonomy, bichirs are polypteriformes and are classified as actinopterygii as opposed to the more derived sarcopterygii. (the two classes in sarcopterygii are dipnoi, which are lungfishes, and actinista, coelacanths). If you need evidence, look up Pough's "Vertebrate Life"- Not having much luck finding a graphic of it for you on google image.

beblondie

#9

Polypterids qualities of both actinopterygii and sarcopterygian and have in the past have been moved between the two categories.Currently the below is valid.

Polypterids are classified as follows

Taxonomic hierarchy

Kingdom Animalia -- Animal

Phylum Chordata -- chordates

Subphylum Vertebrata -- , vertebrates

Superclass Osteichthyes -- bony fishes

Class Actinopterygii -- ray-finned fishes, spiny rayed fishes

Subclass Chondrostei -- paddlefishes, sturgeons

Order Polypteriformes

Family Polypteridae -- bichirs,lobed-finned pike, reed fishes and dinosuar eels

Genus Polypterus

Species(example) Polypterus senegalus- gray bichir-Cuviers bichir
